--none--

* Rebased on top of master.
* Added ServiceResourceTransformer to the common shading configuration to match what was done in #2182 

If there are modules which do not need to shade and relocate Guava - for example if they actively need to not do this and/or we feel that their file size has inflated without any reason - we can add the following <plugin> node to their `<build><plugins>` to "opt-out" of the default shading configuration:
```xml
<plugin>
  <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
  <artifactId>maven-shade-plugin</artifactId>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <id>bundle-and-repackage</id>
      <phase>none</phase>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>
```

Another way to tackle large file sizes would be to configure minimization by default.

I think we should start a minimization track separately from this change, as there are some issues with it:
1. There is a bug in shade-plugin where if minimization is declared on a project with pom packaging it fails. I have created a [ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MSHADE-253) and [PR](https://github.com/apache/maven-plugins/pull/107) with a fix for this but could take a while before it is available to us.
2. Minimization on all of our modules adds a significant amount of build time, which, as discussed, we wish to avoid. (Up from 02:30 mins for a build skipping tests on my laptop to over 5 mins)

Hey dude, I'm already using this code for production, however I added some more to allow parameterizing. 
- Using specific datum encoding is necessary to support 1.8.1's logical type conversions.
- Parameterizing helps with that but also by not having to cast SpecificRecords in another SerDe step in your beam since the ParquetReader/Writer already handles that.

I also think you should at least document how to pass hadoop configuration properties since that's used by parquet and doesn't go through the usual beam options with these code.
I can help contribute some code if you want.

Hey !
Agree with your comments/changes ! Let me improve the PR !
You can also submit PRs on my branch !
I'm resuming my work on this PR (and also others ;)).
Thanks !
Run Flink RunnableOnService

@kennknowles merge done and I fixed most test failures except those like

```
testMissingRunAutoAdd(org.apache.beam.sdk.testing.TestPipelineTest$TestPipelineEnforcementsTest$WithRealPipelineRunner)  Time elapsed: 2.087 sec  <<< ERROR!
akka.pattern.AskTimeoutException: Recipient[Actor[akka://master/user/master#-713556530]] had already been terminated
```
This is because the Gearpump cluster has already been shutdown before returning the `PipelineResult`. Any suggestions ?

I agree that this is a breaking change for the return types, but don't you think this is better? Independently of the different types the whole hierarchy does not make sense, and also remember that the DataStoreIO API is marked as experimental and can still evolve, and this is probably the best moment to make these changes before the stable API no ?

Notice also that I am not breaking the global signature, users still access the PTransform with the same methods:
DatastoreIO.v1().write(), DatastoreIO.v1().deleteEntity() and DatastoreIO.v1().deleteKey()
R: @bjchambers

@iemejia The `Experimental` had to be removed long time ago but is being removed here https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/1369. 

Agreed that it will not change the signature for regular usages, it will still break for something like:
`DatastoreV1.DeleteEntity delete = p.apply(...);`

But I remember the main reason we did not go with `Mutate` approach is because it allows mix and match of delete and write mutations which can suboptimal wrt. Cloud Datastore when done in bulk.
(Btw I agree in general that `Mutate` is better approach abstraction wise)

Can I move the two methods into the parent at least (to avoid the repeated code).
withProjectId(String projectId) and  withLocalhost(String localhost) ?

@iemejia I believe there are two issues. 1) `virtualenv` is not installed by default. This is not a jenkins specific problem, this is the for a basic python installation. 2) `tox` manages a virtualenv, running `tox` inside the virtualenv does not make such sense, but we can switch to it. I am not sure it works correctly or not though (i.e. virtualenv in virtualenv). Even if we address 2), because of 1) we will continue to install user packages.

If we take a step, the instructions for running the maven script does not require setting up a `virtualenv`. It will create one as part of the process and use it. If you think that user installed packages are an issue, we can remove them at the clean phase maybe.
